97328d4b7d427f7b1d3c9044c4f40ca8 (02:17): How do I add a new group and put users into that group The Proper Way on OSX?
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:17): like this
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:17): "apprentice"
97328d4b7d427f7b1d3c9044c4f40ca8 (02:17): I see that editing /etc/group will be futile because of lookupd
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:18): I advise you learn how OSX works, goo.
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:18): er
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:18): LOL
97328d4b7d427f7b1d3c9044c4f40ca8 (02:18): Necrosan: Well, that is what I am trying to do. And you aren't really helpful, are you?
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:18): goo: Netinfodb
97328d4b7d427f7b1d3c9044c4f40ca8 (02:19): Ah. Netinfo Manager. Great :)

d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:19): np
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:19): OSX doesn't look at standard files
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:19): AFAIK
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:19): Well /etc/hosts it does
5e1fcae4ec0c3cb5fe9e7cbe0d1647aa (02:21): yeah, that's an exception, didn't used to be that way either.
fe4712936ea786c3058a51706c49e56e (02:22): err.. os x server doesnt look at /etc/hosts
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:23): rorx: Do you think I should chown all my Disks like / ?
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:23): Or leave myself the owner?
fe4712936ea786c3058a51706c49e56e (02:23): err.. i guess it was os x server doesnt look at /etc/fstab
5e1fcae4ec0c3cb5fe9e7cbe0d1647aa (02:23): Necrosan: I always change / to 0700
5e1fcae4ec0c3cb5fe9e7cbe0d1647aa (02:24): sharkhat: yes, it does use hosts(5), since 10.3 I think.
fe4712936ea786c3058a51706c49e56e (02:24): This file does nothing, contains no useful data, and might go away in
fe4712936ea786c3058a51706c49e56e (02:24): future releases.  Do not depend on this file or its contents.
fe4712936ea786c3058a51706c49e56e (02:24): rorx: yea, i mis spoke, i meant it doesnt use fstab
5e1fcae4ec0c3cb5fe9e7cbe0d1647aa (02:24): it's one of the few flat file that's used, in multiuser
fe4712936ea786c3058a51706c49e56e (02:25): the text above is quoted from the file
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:25): rorx: I want to chmod my Media Disk
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:25): to have the exact same perms
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:25): as my OSX disk
d69bc21fbf2e6d37c5a6d3c73e0a157d (02:26): Or would you advise against that?
5e1fcae4ec0c3cb5fe9e7cbe0d1647aa (02:26): sharkhat: actually fstab can be used as well, just not by default, it's used by disk arbitration for static mounts.
fe4712936ea786c3058a51706c49e56e (02:26): a really fun way around not having privilages in osx, is to select the file, hit 'duplicate' and then you have a copy of the file that you own

fe4712936ea786c3058a51706c49e56e (02:27): rorx: then what is it talking about when it says "This file does nothing, contains no useful data, and might go away in future releases.  Do not depend on this file or its contents."

5e1fcae4ec0c3cb5fe9e7cbe0d1647aa (02:27): Necrosan: I think / by default is 0774, which they had to do because Mac users expect to be able to write to the top of their disk.. but of course, in unix this is a big no no.
5e1fcae4ec0c3cb5fe9e7cbe0d1647aa (02:27): Necrosan: so I change it to 0744
5e1fcae4ec0c3cb5fe9e7cbe0d1647aa (02:28): sharkhat: I think you're talking about /etc/fstab.hd no? fstab doesn't even exist by default.

5e1fcae4ec0c3cb5fe9e7cbe0d1647aa (02:37): scotepi: hostname(1)
0b5c4a1eebab6d8468677877384a76c2 (02:37): scotepi, 'hostname'?
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:40): anyone use parallels?
fbb29c0b493928c28f91c720b5b9835d (02:40): http://www.belightsoft.com/products/imagetricks/overview.php --- sweet app, uses OpenGL and CoreImage to edit images :D
fbb29c0b493928c28f91c720b5b9835d (02:40): aaronf0 yes
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:40): the hdd file is self contained?
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:40): as in i can format the hell out of it, and not touch the disk?
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:41): s/format/partitions and format
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:41): pretty sweet setup...
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:41): hrm
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:41): i wonder how many os's i can get on one .hdd file...
fbb29c0b493928c28f91c720b5b9835d (02:41): yes it is just a file (or files) that sit on your computer, they start off small and expand as needed
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:41): ok, its limited to 8ish gigs or something
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:42): by default, yes
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:42): 8ish gigs is a nice limit to set on that file
fbb29c0b493928c28f91c720b5b9835d (02:43): once again NO
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:43): no?
fbb29c0b493928c28f91c720b5b9835d (02:43): when you pick the OS you want to install Parallels creates a HDD size it thinks is fine for that OS, you can edit that if you wish
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:45): ok
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:45): but there is still a limit on the file if you set one?
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:46): as i dont want that file growing much larger than it should
fbb29c0b493928c28f91c720b5b9835d (02:46): aaronf0 the limit is the size you create
b1ad04dfb8f3db9bc1da43499f7abf26 (02:47): ok
